trans-unit.source: Azure Service Fabric Actors Distributed Networks and Graphs design pattern
trans-unit.target: Azure Service Fabric Actors Distributed Networks and Graphs design pattern

trans-unit.source: Design pattern on how Service Fabric Actors can be used to model application as distributed networks and graphs
trans-unit.target: Design pattern on how Service Fabric Actors can be used to model application as distributed networks and graphs

trans-unit.source: Service Fabric Reliable Actors is a natural fit for modeling complex solutions involving relations and modeling those relations as objects.
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric Reliable Actors is a natural fit for modeling complex solutions involving relations and modeling those relations as objects.

trans-unit.source: As the diagram illustrates it is straightforward to model a user as an actor instance (node in the network).
trans-unit.target: As the diagram illustrates it is straightforward to model a user as an actor instance (node in the network).

trans-unit.source: For example, the “Friends Feed” (sometimes referred as the "follower" problem) allows users to view status updates from people they are connected to, similar to how Facebook and Twitter work.
trans-unit.target: For example, the “Friends Feed” (sometimes referred as the "follower" problem) allows users to view status updates from people they are connected to, similar to how Facebook and Twitter work.

trans-unit.source: The Actor model provides flexibility to approach the materialization problem.
trans-unit.target: The Actor model provides flexibility to approach the materialization problem.

trans-unit.source: We can populate the Friends Feed at event time, updating the Friends Feed of all my friends at the moment an update is posted, as illustrated below:
trans-unit.target: We can populate the Friends Feed at event time, updating the Friends Feed of all my friends at the moment an update is posted, as illustrated below:

trans-unit.source: Sample code populating Friends Feed:
trans-unit.target: Sample code populating Friends Feed:

trans-unit.source: Alternatively we can model our Actors to fan out and compile the Friends Feed at the query timer, in other words when the user asks for their friends feed.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively we can model our Actors to fan out and compile the Friends Feed at the query timer, in other words when the user asks for their friends feed.

trans-unit.source: Another method we can use is materializing the Friends Feed on a timer, for example, every 5 minutes.
trans-unit.target: Another method we can use is materializing the Friends Feed on a timer, for example, every 5 minutes.

trans-unit.source: Or, we can optimize the model and combine both event time and query time processing with a timer-based model depending on user habits, such as how often they login or post an update.
trans-unit.target: Or, we can optimize the model and combine both event time and query time processing with a timer-based model depending on user habits, such as how often they login or post an update.

trans-unit.source: When modelling an actor in a social network, one should also consider “super users,” users with millions of followers.
trans-unit.target: When modelling an actor in a social network, one should also consider “super users,” users with millions of followers.

trans-unit.source: Developers should model the state and behaviour of such users differently to meet the demand.
trans-unit.target: Developers should model the state and behaviour of such users differently to meet the demand.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, if we want to model an activity that connects many user actors to a single activity actor (hub and spoke) that can be done as well.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, if we want to model an activity that connects many user actors to a single activity actor (hub and spoke) that can be done as well.

trans-unit.source: Group chat or game hosting scenarios are two examples.
trans-unit.target: Group chat or game hosting scenarios are two examples.

trans-unit.source: Let’s take the group chat example; a set of participants create a group chat actor that can distribute messages from one participant to the group as in the example below:
trans-unit.target: Let’s take the group chat example; a set of participants create a group chat actor that can distribute messages from one participant to the group as in the example below:

trans-unit.source: All it really does is leverage Reliable Actors' ability to allow any actor to address any other actor in the cluster by id and communicate with it without needing to worry about placement, addressing, caching, messaging, serialization, or routing.
trans-unit.target: All it really does is leverage Reliable Actors' ability to allow any actor to address any other actor in the cluster by id and communicate with it without needing to worry about placement, addressing, caching, messaging, serialization, or routing.
